Subject: Cantera MATLAB Toolbox
Message-ID: <aa3m86+8fj3@...>
User-Agent: eGroups-EW/0.82
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

X-Yahoo-Profile: dggoodwin

I recented visited Michael Frenklach at UC Berkeley who convinced me 
of the usefulness of MATLAB, and showed me the impressive graphical 
MATLAB applications he is developing for kinetics.

Inspired by this visit, I decided to develop a Cantera MATLAB toolbox 
that provides access to many features of Cantera from within MATLAB, 
including chemical equilibrium, thermodynamic properties, reaction 
properties, transport properties, and reactor models.

The first version of this toolbox is now available for download at 
http://blue.caltech.edu/cantera-mlab-10.zip. Tutorials and examples 
are provided that illustrate how to use it.

The toolbox includes a reactor function with user-specified dV/dt and 
heat flux that allows virtually any zero-dimensional kinetics 
simulation to be carried out. With a few minor modifications reactor 
networks could be simulated. The reactor function is written in 
Matlab's scripting language, so it can be quickly modified and run 
with no need to compile or link anything. MATLAB's own stiff ODE 
integrators can be used for integration. (See examples/ignite.m for 
an example of its use.)

Benchmark kinetics simulations in MATLAB with GRI-Mech 3.0 take a few 
seconds  on a typical PC. This is much slower than the same 
simulation done in C++ with Cantera (~ 0.5 s), but still very 
reasonable, and the ease of customizing the calculation more than 
compensates for the slower performance. (If speed really matters, 
MATLAB includes the ability to compile '.m' functions to C code.)

This diversion has delayed my promised update to the Cantera Python 
interface... this is next up.
